newsitem.title: MEXICO: Mexico peso mixed on pre-weekend swaps.
newsitem.headline: Mexico peso mixed on pre-weekend swaps.

text.p: The Mexican peso was mixed in early trade on Friday due to pre-weekend swaps but was firm on most contracts due to demand for local money market paper, traders said.
"Dealers are trading on interest-rate arbitrage because rates are attractive in Mexico, especially at six months," a trader said.
The benchmark 48-hour peso was 0.35 centavo firmer in early trade at 7.8700/7.8740 per dollar, while its 24-hour counterpart was 0.5 of a centavo firmer at 7.8660/7.8700 per dollar.
Same-day peso contracts were meanwhile 1.2 centavos firmer at 7.8540/7.8580 per dollar.

Dealers said brokers were selling dollars in the same-day market to buy them back at 24 hours, with the advantage that the latter contracts do not require settlement until Monday, using pesos that may meanwhile be invested in the money market.
Traders said stable U.S. long bond yields also helped bolster the peso. U.S. 30-year Treasury bonds were unchnaged to yield 7.07 percent.
Dealers predicted a trading range of 7.8600/7.8800 per dollar for 48-hour peso contracts.
